Dr.K,

UI has little impact on the jobs problem. The problem is wages are too low.

As I see it, we need to collectively create jobs to manufacture & grow products or create services that can compete globally as well as in our own market. This is America's success track .

Admittedly, this goal is a sticky wicket but we can do it. At the core of the strategy is paying livable wages in the US for the work & we must hang on to this principle if we are to recover.

There are very promising future products & services rising out of the global warming threat. We can build green products that the World will want to buy but we have to make a collective effort through government to focus our capitol on this capacity. The government role in WWII to create an aircraft and shipbuilding industry comes to mind. Think about Henry J. Kaiser from sand and gravel to 1 ship a day.

I am pushing making fertilizer out of coal, and nitrogen cooled superconducting magnets for transport of passengers and freight trucks at 300 mph rather than buying foreign steel wheel passenger rail systems. I am also pushing using these powerful magnets to launch space payload very cheaply so that we can mount solar power satellites in orbit to beam power to dipole antennae farms making cheap electric power available to everyone on earth.

The market economy is not working or we would have plenty of jobs. It is obvious to me that government must intervene and put a Tesla or a Volt in every garage.

A Dr. Katherine Abraham, an MIT labor economics prof and later Clinton's director of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, prepared a report for the Labor Dept in Feb. 1982 that finally was mentioned in the news in June or July of that year on openings and jobs. She found by two methods that during the entire decade of the 1970s, there were five jobseekers for EVERY opening in the nation. She also estimated that the national jobless rate would have to fall to about 3% to bring seekers into equality with openings. That low jobless rate was approximately achieved during the last few years of the Clinton administration.

Now, we are having net job growth of perhaps 180,000 per month, when we have 12 or 18 million jobless people who'd rather be working. SO---the real ratio of seekers to openings is on the order of 50 or 100 seekers per opening, tho some aren't actively seeking because of discouragement, etc. That's pretty (expletive) awful, and the indifference of Obama and Democrats to this situation is baffling. Never mind the GOP, they're beyond redemption.

The employment/population ratio topped at 64% around 2000 and it's now at 58.6%. That includes the young and old and spouses, not just the prime-age males. We have a colossal gap between what is and what could be, impinging on the revenue that could be paid too. And the wasted lives are tantamount to genocide. I've been of the LT jobless and know how it feels.

"This editorial mimics mainstream U.S. propaganda that objections to surveillance are merely "playacting" as all governments know we snoop into their most private communications".

Actually, if you read the editorial, it makes the opposite point. It may be a given that governments spy (i.e. collect information) on other governments. Always have and always will. What the editorial points out is that the collection of information of private citizens (not government officials) should be regulated.

And in a complex world, the bottom line is always a lot fuzzier than you'd like. There may have been liars who led us into war, but there were also many who wanted to believe the lies and many who didn't care what the truth was. Who should be put in jail? The then President, the Congress, the newspapers and major media, the people who elected and re-elected their gullible representatives? And do we know for sure what the consequences of Snowden's one-sided disclosures are? Answer those questions and then maybe you'll understand that a complex world doesn't favor the blithe and naive.

Are we overlooking the fact that Snowden did not work for the U.S. government, but rather for a private spy agency that sells the use of its snooping expertise to the highest bidder? This is a business, guys, and no doubt a profitable one at that.  It is here to stay and simply will move off shore if given too much trouble here.

Okay, what is out government doing that is illegal? Do you believe they broke criminal laws? If so, what laws? Intrusions? Tell me what intrusions and what was done that was illegal. Look, I don't know and I believe you do not know what actually has happened. What I do know is there have been a lot of people mashing their teeth over whether they have been spied upon yet they really do not know. I can also say that if what NSA has done is against the constitution, then someone, anyone should step up and  file a law suit. I realize it is difficult since everything has certain protections, but from what I have seen, along with 35 years of the practice of law including 7 years as a prosecutor, I cannot see where there is any criminal activity. I say this because I can be convinced either way but as of now I take the president and the folks involved at their word. Now, if you are one of those anti-government folks who see boogie men everywhere, I cannot help you.On the other hand I agree that Bush started two stupid wars. Now Obama handled Iraq properly and well Afghanistan is well Afghanistan. There is no good answer other than getting out and hope something good happens. In long run we have to elect the best people and hope they do the right thing.

Even the Times Editorial Board seems to be tiptoeing around the obvious malfeasance and illegality of what our government is doing in the name of National Security. That really is the trump card isn't it, this Administration and its predecessor claiming that lives will be saved by their endless intrusions. What about the number of lives which could have been saved without two needless, preemptive wars, which by the way, some on the Times staff supported at the time.

I don't think European governments are conflating anything, and the faux argument that 'well, everyone is doing it, and all governments know it' certainly seems a rationale for supporting unprecedented spying on Americans and millions of other people, and our allies, around the globe.

No amount of whitewashing will change that.

With House districts that are carefully gerrymandered by Republican state legislators, the biggest fear of far right Republicans in the House is to face an even more far right Republican in the primaries. We have a big problem. Our general lassitude about our rights as citizens has allowed both Republicans and Democrats to take away fair voting by skewing districts to suit their needs, not the needs of voters or the fundamentals of democracy. Yet, we, the people, have no clear way to overrule what has been done. Without gerrymandering, the Republicans would not control the House now or, at best, they would do so with a very slim majority.

I live in Maryland where Democrats are in control. In the 20 or so years I have lived in this same community, the House district lines have been redrawn so that we have had three different representatives. Now, we have a congressman whose main interests are in Baltimore, not in the DC suburbs (the Dems are trying to get rid of a long serving Republican who, until now, has represented the more rural, western part of Maryland). This process is wrong, no matter who does it.

The system is absolutely broken. Social Security was NEVER EVER designed to support 10% of the population, for their entire lives, on disability. The disability clause was added afterwards, and for decades, it was only there for the most pitiful cases -- quadriplegics, people in iron lungs. The truly disabled.

Then under Clinton, the standards were drastically loweredd. Now you could get FULL SSI disability pay -- for life -- if you were "mildly chronically depressed' or had unprovable "back pain" or "social anxiety". Since these things are self-described and unprovable by objective means, anyone who reads up on the symptoms can easily qualify.

Anyone with a TV set knows that sleazebag lawyers advertise on TV how "anyone can get SSDI! call us! dozens of new categories now you can qualify under!" (*actual verifiable commercial) -- and with an attorney, you virtually cannot be denied, even if it takes 20 months to get SSDI. Whole legions of quack doctors exist just to rubber stamp applications (for money).

So now fully one American in 10 (between 18 and 65) is on Social Security Disability Insurance. If you earned a good living, you could be receiving as much as $3200 a month! for life! starting at age 35! (*I actually know one such person, so I know it is a fact.) You also get many privileges for being "disabled", such as priority for Section 8 housing, free bus passes, low interest mortgages and more.

Now imagine 12 million illegals going for the brass ring of SSDI....

"Social security has nothing to do with economics."

Absolutely ridiculous! Tell that to my 95-year-old dad who worked his entire life until about age 70, who served his country in the Army for five years (1941-45) during World War II, and who lost his pension after working for a company for more than 40 years when it was bought out by another company when he was in his late fifties. Except for the modest help provided by my brother and I, Social Security benefits (and Medicare) are what have kept him from living in complete poverty for the last 25 years, and his annual income is only about $15,000.

Now, "jorod," that has something important to do with economics that you appear to be incapable of understanding. Alas!

Two weeks ago, a good friend, a single mom, due to divorce, whose 2 children are grown, told us she was summoned one afternoon early in the month of June.
June is her birth month.
Last Sunday, she turned 60 years old.
She is a registered nurse and had worked for the same hospital for 36 years.
She has a 401(k).
They told her that as of that day, she was no longer employed at the hospital.
No severance, health care coverage to the end of the month (which she'd already paid for).
A fellow nurse went to her locker and delivered contents to her at the door.
Security was detailed to see to it that she walked out without talking to anyone.
36 years -- not even a "thank you" for her many years of perseverance and good work.
Social Security unavailable for another 2 years.
Copra won't even kick in for about 6 weeks (it takes that long to process an application).
There is no doubt that she wasn't the only one who got this treatment in the hospital.
The psychological blow was enormous.
My husband went through the same experience when he was 58 in 2003.
Her life changed in an instant.
She's collecting unemployment and preparing to sell her home and move near her son.
She'll get another job, but it won't come easy.
Thank God, she's in good health.

In PA, you have to be ACTIVELY looking for work and the state can call you in at any time and you have to prove you've been looking for work. I've been called in twice since October.
When I was on unemployment 10 years ago--there was no requirement to prove you were looking for work. NOW---the state has a website that you track your job search on. You can't tell me that the dept of labor and industry doesn't check on this site and see what you're doing. You are required to do 4 job applications a week if you're not working part-time. If you're part-time--you are required to do 2 job applications a week.
Oh--and the jobs I'm able to get? How does $10 an hour sound thru a temp agency? No health care (except my Cobra), no holidays, no PTO and you could be working for different people every week.
Or not live, as the case may be...

We might be seeing the last gasps of the Republican party. Really. It seems they are making so much noise now because perhaps they, too, realize that the end is near. There is no reason to assume that brittle, angry ideologies should last forever. The world was once about 1/3 communist, now not even China is truly a communist nation. The amount of change that is coming our way will require active, interventionist governments or some kind of massive citizen organization effort to decide and do things on our own. It is not going to be possible to argue for small government for matters such as our energy future and allocation of land and resources any more than such an argument would hold in a time of global warfare. Look at how quickly the Republicans abandoned their "hands off" policies when the chips were down on a world wide economic collapse in 2008. A great deal of the ideology of the Republican party is just something to feed the willing masses while they go about other matters.
Solution: don't vote for a Republican at the local, state, and national levels in 2014 and 2016. We need to take back our country.
